intro: Galium longipedunculatum, commonly known as the long-stemmed bedstraw, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family, which includes over 13,000 species of flowering plants. The plant is characterized by its slender, branching stems and small, opposite leaves that are often hairy. Its flowers are white or pale green, arranged in clusters at the ends of the stems, and it produces small, dry fruits called schizocarps. Galium longipedunculatum is often found in moist, shaded habitats such as woodlands and stream banks.
